laws.summary: Massachusetts regulates non-compete agreements through the Massachusetts Noncompetition Agreement Act (MNAA). Non-competes are enforceable if: (1) in writing and signed by both parties, (2) provided with offer or 10 business days before employment, (3) employee notified of right to consult attorney, (4) supported by garden leave (50% salary) or other consideration, (5) reasonable in scope and duration (max 1 year for most employees). Certain professions are prohibited: physicians, nurses, psychologists, social workers, broadcasters, lawyers, non-exempt employees under FLSA, employees terminated without cause.
requirements: Must be in writing and signed by employer and employee
Must be presented at formal offer or 10 business days before employment start
Employee must be advised of right to consult counsel
Must provide garden leave (50% highest annual salary during restriction) or other mutually agreed consideration
Maximum duration of 1 year for most workers
Must be reasonable in geographic scope
Must protect legitimate business interest (trade secrets, confidential information)
Cannot be used for non-exempt FLSA employees
Cannot be used for employees terminated without cause or laid off
Specific professions banned: physicians (c. 112 §12X), nurses (c. 112 §74D), psychologists (c. 112 §129B), social workers (c. 112 §135C), broadcasters (c. 149 §186), lawyers (Mass. R. Prof. C. 5.6)
laws.notes: Federal FTC ban was blocked in 2024. Massachusetts law continues to govern. Recent SJC case Miele v. Foundation Medicine (2025) narrowed scope - non-solicitation agreements with forfeiture provisions may be subject to MNAA requirements.

laws.summary: Massachusetts prohibits employers from seeking salary history information from job applicants until after extending an offer with compensation. Employers cannot screen applicants based on salary history or require disclosure of prior wages. This is part of the Massachusetts Equal Pay Act.
requirements: Employers may not ask about wage or salary history until AFTER making an offer of employment with compensation
Cannot require applicants to disclose salary history
Cannot screen applicants based on salary history
Cannot use prior salary alone to justify pay differences
Applies to all private employers in Massachusetts
laws.notes: One of the first salary history ban laws in the United States. Designed to address gender and racial wage gaps.

laws.summary: Massachusetts requires employers with 25+ employees to disclose salary ranges in job postings and to employees upon request. The Salary Range Transparency Law aims to increase equity and close wage gaps.
laws.statute_citation: M.G.L. c. 149, § 105F (An Act Relative to Salary Range Transparency)
requirements: Applies to employers with 25+ employees whose primary place of work is Massachusetts
Must include annual salary range or hourly wage range in ALL job postings
Pay range = what employer 'reasonably and in good faith expects to pay at that time'
Must disclose range to employees offered promotion/transfer to new position
Must provide range to current employees for their position upon request
Must disclose for positions that can be performed remotely to MA worksite
For commission/piece rate positions: must include commission or piece rate range
Remote employees whose primary place of work is MA are covered
Anti-retaliation protections for employees requesting pay information
First offense: warning | Second: up to $500 fine | Third: up to $1,000 | Fourth+: $7,500-$25,000
2-business day grace period to cure violations (until October 29, 2027)
laws.notes: Signed into law July 31, 2024. No private right of action - enforced exclusively by Attorney General. Employers with 100+ employees must also file EEO-1 reports to Secretary of Commonwealth by Feb 1 annually.

laws.summary: Massachusetts has a comprehensive 'Ban the Box' law that prohibits employers from asking about criminal history on initial job applications. Criminal record inquiries are restricted to later stages of hiring with specific limitations on what can be asked and how records can be used.
laws.statute_citation: M.G.L. c. 151B, § 4(9½) (Ban the Box); M.G.L. c. 6, §§ 167-178B (CORI Law)
requirements: Cannot ask about criminal history on initial written job application
Cannot ask about arrests, detentions, or dispositions that did not result in conviction
Cannot ask about misdemeanors older than 3 years (changed from 5 years in 2018)
Cannot ask about first convictions for certain misdemeanors
Cannot ask about sealed or expunged records
Felony convictions: limited to 7 years lookback
Must provide copy of criminal records before taking adverse action
Must conduct individualized assessment - cannot automatically reject applicants with records
Exceptions for positions legally prohibited from hiring people with records (childcare, some financial)
Must notify employee of right to review CORI before adverse action
CORI background checks (Criminal Offender Record Information) show MA state court records only
laws.notes: Massachusetts was second state (after Hawaii) to ban both public and private employers from criminal history questions on applications. Attorney General enforces - can impose $5,000 fines. Civil Rights Division handles complaints.

laws.summary: Massachusetts Earned Sick Time Law requires most employers to provide up to 40 hours of earned sick time per year. Employees earn 1 hour for every 30 hours worked. Sick time is paid for employers with 11+ employees, unpaid for smaller employers.
laws.statute_citation: M.G.L. c. 149, §§ 148C and 148D (Massachusetts Earned Sick Time Law)
requirements: Employers with 11+ employees: must provide PAID sick time
Employers with 10 or fewer employees: must provide UNPAID sick time
Employees earn at least 1 hour sick time per 30 hours worked
Maximum 40 hours earned sick time per year
Sick time begins accruing from first hour worked
Cannot use sick time until after 90 days of employment
Must allow carryover of up to 40 hours year-to-year (not required to allow more)
Can use for: employee illness/injury, medical appointments, child/spouse/parent/spouse's parent illness
Can use for domestic violence situations affecting employee or children
Can use for pregnancy loss or failed assisted reproduction/adoption/surrogacy (added 2024)
Employers can require up to 7 days notice for planned absences
Must post Notice of Employee Rights in workplace
NOT required to pay out unused sick time at termination
Records must be maintained for 3 years
laws.notes: Passed by ballot measure in 2014. Does not apply to: certain public employees, independent contractors, employees in work-study programs. Attorney General's Fair Labor Division enforces. SJC ruled accrued sick time is NOT 'wages' under Wage Act.

laws.summary: Massachusetts generally enforces arbitration agreements but has specific requirements. For employment discrimination claims, arbitration agreements must explicitly cite the specific types of claims (e.g., gender discrimination) to be arbitrable. Courts apply federal law favoring arbitration but with state-specific limitations.
laws.statute_citation: M.G.L. c. 251 (Uniform Arbitration Act for Commercial Disputes)
requirements: Arbitration agreements must be in writing
For discrimination claims: agreement must explicitly cite specific claim types to be arbitrable
Broad arbitration clauses may not cover statutory employment discrimination claims without explicit mention
Court must find agreement 'valid, enforceable and irrevocable'
Employer can waive right to compel arbitration through litigation conduct
Warfield v. Beth Israel Deaconess (2009): employee can proceed to court if agreement doesn't explicitly cite discrimination
Massachusetts public policy strongly favors arbitration for commercial disputes
For certain professions: collective bargaining agreements may mandate grievance arbitration
Agreement terms can be challenged on unconscionability grounds (though rarely successful)
laws.notes: Massachusetts is minority jurisdiction requiring explicit mention of discrimination claims in arbitration agreements. Employers adding arbitration mid-contract may face enforceability challenges. Must have written agreement - unwritten agreements not enforceable per Crean v. Morgan Stanley (2023).

laws.summary: Massachusetts follows at-will employment doctrine - either party can terminate employment at any time for any legal reason or no reason. However, numerous exceptions protect employees from wrongful termination including discrimination, retaliation, public policy violations, and implied contracts.
laws.statute_citation: Common law doctrine with statutory exceptions under M.G.L. c. 151B (anti-discrimination), M.G.L. c. 149 (wage/hour protections)
requirements: Default rule: employment can be terminated at any time by employer or employee
No requirement for notice or cause UNLESS contract/policy states otherwise
Discharged employees must be paid in full on day of discharge (M.G.L. c. 149, § 148)
Voluntary resignation: paid on next regular payday

EXCEPTIONS - Cannot terminate for: discrimination (race, gender, age 40+, disability, religion, national origin, sexual orientation, gender identity, genetic info, pregnancy); retaliation for protected activities (workers comp claim, jury duty, whistleblowing, reporting violations, refusing illegal acts); violation of public policy (reporting employer illegal conduct, refusing to break law); breach of implied contract (employee handbook promises, verbal assurances of job security)
Union/collective bargaining agreements override at-will status
Employees with written employment contracts have additional protections
laws.notes: While doctrine is straightforward, Robert S. Mantell notes 'validity is dwarfed by its numerous exceptions.' MCAD (Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination) and EEOC enforce discrimination protections. Public policy exception crafted by MA courts protects whistleblowers.

laws.summary: Massachusetts has no statute directly regulating private employer drug testing. Case law (Webster v. Motorola) establishes that drug testing must balance employer business interests against employee privacy rights. Random testing limited to safety-sensitive positions. Medical marijuana users have some protections; recreational users have minimal workplace protections.
laws.statute_citation: No specific statute; governed by case law - Webster v. Motorola, 423 Mass. 425 (1996); Barbuto v. Advantage Sales, 477 Mass. 456 (2017)
requirements: Pre-employment testing: Generally allowed if applied consistently to all applicants in similar roles
Post-hire testing: Must be job-related and consistent with business necessity
Random testing: Limited to safety-sensitive positions (e.g., driving company vehicles, operating machinery, positions affecting public safety)
Blanket random testing without distinguishing job types is NOT permitted
Must balance employer's business/safety interests vs. employee privacy rights
MEDICAL MARIJUANA: Employers must provide reasonable accommodation for off-duty medical marijuana use (unless impairs job performance)
Medical marijuana patients protected under disability discrimination law (M.G.L. c. 151B)
On-site marijuana use is never protected - employers can prohibit
RECREATIONAL MARIJUANA: No workplace protections for recreational users
Employers can maintain zero-tolerance policies and terminate for positive tests, even for off-duty use
Pending legislation (H.2179, H.3751) may ban pre-employment marijuana testing except for safety-sensitive positions
Federal contractors must comply with federal drug-free workplace requirements
laws.notes: Medical marijuana legal since 2012, recreational since 2016. Marijuana remains federally illegal. Testing technology cannot determine current impairment - only past use. Webster v. Motorola key case: upheld testing for sales rep driving 25,000 mi/year but not for technical writer with no safety concerns. Barbuto case requires interactive process for medical marijuana accommodation. Proposed bills would prohibit pre-employment marijuana testing starting 2025-2026.

data_quality.sources: Official Massachusetts government websites (mass.gov), Massachusetts General Laws, case law, Attorney General guidance

additional_notes.general_guidance: Massachusetts is a worker-friendly state with strong employment protections. Employers must carefully balance operational needs with numerous employee protections under state and federal law.
enforcement_agencies: Massachusetts Attorney General's Office - Fair Labor Division
recent_developments: Pay transparency law effective Oct 29, 2025 - major compliance requirement
Earned sick time expanded Nov 2024 to include pregnancy loss
Pending legislation may ban pre-employment marijuana testing
Federal FTC non-compete ban blocked Aug 2024 - state law governs
